title: Does anyone feel that Adolf Hitler was a bit justified for his actions? - Quora

response.answer_text: Justifiable? No. Understandable? Yes, to an extent—for Germany at least, not necessarily for Hitler specifically. (Context: I am an American Jew, but I have no familial connections to the Holocaust—my relatives had left Europe long before). Why? I put it this way: if you took America, and subjected us to a treaty which, while arguably fair, was certainly harsh and well-designed to cripple our economy; put us into two extreme depressions in rapid succession; sold us a lot of propaganda about how our military had been betrayed in a war we should have won; crippled our military; and threw in an existing, and common at the time, prejudice; what do you think would happen? We’d go to war is what would happen (and we’re not exactly known for placing nice as it is… see Vietnam, Iraq). Oh, and judging by our track record with the Japanese (the American ones, I mean)—we’d probably also have a Holocaust. So, while Germany’s actions were clearly abhorrent, they were, I think, little different from what many countries at the time would have done under similar conditions. Actually, put it this way: Donald Trump stands a viable chance at getting elected, with an alarmingly fascist and nationalist platform, under circumstances far less extreme than what Germany faced. I rest my case (that an angry populace easily turns to fascism—I’m not saying Donald Trump’s America would be fascist). Note: I am not saying that Trump in practice would be fascist, and it is his followers I am referring to, not him (stands a viable chance at being elected, not just running). However, many of his statements—more to the point, many of the statements supported by a concerning number of Americans—include aspects which are authoritarian, populist and nationalist, i.e., fascist.

Absolutely not. The only possible justification was the Versailles Treaty. And Hitler used it because it was so unpopular with the German people. Even some non-Germans saw it as too punitive. There were some including important figures outside of Germany who also saw it as too punitive. There are, however, some important aspects to remember. As Clemenceau said after World War I , “Belgium did not invade Germany.”Aspects of German policy was to impose upon others what they claimed was unfair. Notice the terms the Germans imposed upon France after the Franco-Prussian War. Some of the very same actions they objected to when imposed upon Germany. Franco Prussian War - impactActually the Versailles Treaty was MILD compared with the peace the Germans imposed upon the Russians (1918)—the treaty of Brest-Litovsk (1918). Again the Germans did not really objects to the terms, the only problem with Versailles was that it was imposed upon Germany. They wanted to do the imposing.http://histclo.com/essay/war/ww1/misc/ww1-bl.htmlGermany objected to Germans being ruled by non-Germans while at the same time in the east, Poles were being ruled by Germans. And the Austrians were a small minority in the Austrian/Austro-Hungarian Empire. The only German majority area detached permanently was the Sudetenland (former Austrian territory) and Danzig (turned into an international city). Versailles called for a series of referendums where the locl population decided on their future. The problem for the Germans was that they were a minority, so most of the referenda went against them. What the Germans wanted was special rules for themselves and the right to rule other people. .Compare German World War I occupation say in Belgium to Allied occupation. The German Army in Belgium seized the food supply and left the Belgians to starve. This was only prevented when America stepped in to feed Belgium. The very limited occupation after Versailles meant that the Allies arrived with food.Germany food shortagesWorld War I Versilles Peace Treaty

Hitler was not a German nationalist and did not care about Germany, He was an Austrian moving to Germany at the outbreak of World War I. When he died at his own hand in 1945 he told the German nation - in no uncertain terms - that he condemned them to total destruction for having disappointed him endlessly. He certainly did not love Germany. As somebody who could not love himself (he subsconsciously knew that he was inferior in Adler´s inferiority complex fashion and hadto overcompensate with lies) love (also patriotism) had left his life for good. Versailles was a curse that he could and did use for his self-aggrangizement and overcompensation purposes. France especially had used Versailles to revenge herself on Germany for the victory of 1871. Germany´s (Wilhelm II´s) stupidities and greed had contributed to the outbreak of World War I. But there was no sole culpability for a war that was a powder keg of imperial controversies and conflagrations that just needed a tiny spark to explode. Versailles was unfair and its reparations broke the back of post-Wilhelm II Germany and tainted whatever real democracy the Weimar Republic had established, The cultural blossoming of Weimar Germany was astonishing and impressive but could be wiped away by a countermovement far too easily. Versailles had established Weimar Germany but had not cared about guardians and sound development principles. Hitler was the proverbial confidence-trickster - the carpet bagger, quack physician, fraudster and mobster: a con-man. So he invented an Aryan identity that never existed and found stupid Germans in search of an aristocracy of the genetic endowment (Wilhelm II had deserted Germany for his Dutch exile after 1918). Then he hooked on what could be called a Warfare Keynesianism: Run up deficits to restart the industrial machine of a well-industrialized nation. When the deficits loom large start a war so that the victims of German expansion pay for the deficit you have accrued. All this was not genius, foresight or planning. It was a con-man´s ability to use the moment for his self-aggrandizement plans. The little man wanting to be ÜBERMENSCH (superman) only had to find a congregation who believed his Big Man lies (“I am strength personified!”). Masses believing in Big Man lies in actual fact make little men larger than life and do not understand that they have made the FÜHRER (leader, conducator) themselves. They adore a mirage they themselves have created by abdicating all wills of their own, all reason and integrity. Hitler was illogical, ignorant, immoral and a total disaster. That he fooled the Germans and the great Western democracies and the Eastern democracy turned evil in the Kremlin was not genius but gambler´s luck. In 1918, in 1945 and in 1990 there were regime changes: get rid of totalitarian rule and the sunrise of democracy will come about inevitably. Well, history teaches us that things do not work like that. Regime changes (say “Get rid of the establishment in Washington, Silicon Valley, Hollywood and academia and the nation of little people belittled beyond belief will wake up in patriotic grandeur. Just trust in your military and in your prophets of grandeur! It is all a matter of confidence - trick or treat!) are totally over-rated. To answer the question briefly. Hitler spotted some real problems and developed a certain logic. But he was wrong in principle and totally disinterested in truth. (Why should I search for truth when I can achieve power more easily with half-truths and outright lies.) He felt contempt for the audiences he addressed. He thought they were despicably gulllible and “feminine” (weibisch) in their readiness to be manipulated by his verbal tricks. Con-men are not interested in the fabric of reality but in the fabrication of reality. Give me your confidence and I´ll use it for my own purposes.

Ok, not a Nazi sympathizer either, but the actions you could justify would be regarding the economic changes he made to bring Germany out of their depression. He did inspire people to believe in Germany as a great nation again, and there's nothing inherently wrong with that concept... However, even these things later led to discrimination of women (regarding appropriate roles in society), Jews, and other ethnicities. There were a lot of things he did that were mostly good in the beginning, but nearly everything that started with Germany's socialist beliefs in caring for your fellow German turned into despising those who the regime deemed inferior. This site is in my opinion ignoring some details, but is at least informative. 12 Things You Were Not Told About Adolph Hitler and Nazi Germany

No. By 1933 Germany had ceased to pay reparations. By 1936 Hitler had remilitarized the Rhineland; in 1938 he annexed Austria and later the same year he had added the Sudetenland to Germany. The Versailles Treaty was in tatters, but he still had boundless ambitions. By October 1938 the treaty was no longer a remotely valid excuse for any of his actions.

Um how many times can I write no, before this answer gets pulled. Here's the real world to me. We should be judged not only by what we do or say, but "the Hitler test", or "the Manson defense" of 1969 helps define the difference between good and evil. Because it goes further to ask, what would a reasonably sane person expect to result from.their speech or action? So...no.no No no no no no hell no no, no no no, no. No. He may have had some legitimate problems with the way Germany was treated. But sane people don't act the way he did And so, no again.

The only….and I mean ONLY thing that I can perhaps say I am on the same page with the Nazi government of the time was the unfairness of the “corridor” and the need for Poland to return that stripe of territory to Germany.  It was a very ill-conceived idea and was kind of a dumb thing to try and do. To separate East Prussia from the main part of Germany and then deny them access expect by the sea was nothing less than a continued taunt that they had lost the First World War. Yes, Poland needed sea access, but there were SO many other ways to go about doing it rather than take the corridor from Germany and then make it so difficult for the Germans to have land access to East Prussia. Now, with that said, invading Poland to get it back was not the answer, not the answer at all, since that action started World War II.

Justified in killing himself? Yes! He could've done it sooner , but better late than never. Justified in starting a war of aggression and starting the extermination of the Jews and Slavs? Of course not! You literally have to be mentally ill or delusional to actually think that anything Hitler did was "justified".

I cannot think of anything he did that was justified. Even before the WW2, the way he came to power, his ideology etc. Everything he did was the opposite what Germany and German people really needed. He was a manipulator who took advantage of people having really difficult times.

I cannot tell if you are asking for other people's opinion or asking if he was infact a good person blinded by wrong things. I can give you many sources as to why I believe he was a good person see one of my answers Raha Khani's answer to Was Hitler really as evil as he is portrayed, or was it propaganda by Soviets and allies? Or you can watch this one hour video if you really wanna know what actually happened. And judge at the end for yourself if he was or not.
If by “his actions” you mean that Adolf Hitler actually KILLED Adolf Hitler, then yes, I do feel he was a bit justified.

Stalin is responsible for many many more deaths than Hitler, yet there is no such stigma attached to him. Incidentally, Hitler was not responsible for the creation of the final solution Himler was, but Himlers orginal plan was the repatriation of Jews to Palestine. He even had a special commemorative medal struck (one side swastika other side star of David). This did start to happen, however with the out break of war and the fact that the British controlled Palestine it couldn't continue.
I for one, think that at least one action he took was a correct one. It was his very last one!! It was a great move on his part. Just wish he made it about 5 years sooner.
Does anyone feel that Adolf Hitler was a bit justified for his actions? Yes Many And more than “a bit.” MOST of them have examined BOTH sides instead of blindly believing either side’s propaganda.
Did he kill a lot ? oh yes he did….. within his beliefs though people justify the mass killings as long as is done under the name of religion or “God”… can you believe the irony?

I think good leaders do mistakes . So they make some bad decisions . Bad leaders also do mistakes and those mistakes are some good decisions. Maybe the only good things was improving the economy and reviving the industry and infrastructure development. Thee improvements probably were just side effect … the goal was a stronger army to wage war.
You're not a nazi sympathizer, you say, but you ask a question to evokes sympathy for Hitler. If it walks and quacks like a duck, it's a duck. You're a nazi sympathizer.
